Notes General:

CENSUS INFORMATION: In the 1920 US Census, he is listed as Carl Graham, aged 2 years and 9 months, and born in Iowa. He is living with his parents, 2 brothers and a sister, in Linn street, Waterloo Ward 4, Black Hawk, Iowa. (Supervisors District 3, Enumeration District 33, Sheet 2A).

In the 1925 State Census of Iowa, he is listed as Carl B. Graham, aged 7 and born in Iowa. He is living in Waterloo, Black Hawk, Iowa, with his parents, 2 brothers and a sister. (Iowa, U.S., State Census Collection, 1836-1925 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA).

In the 1930 US Census, he is listed as Carl Graham, aged 12 and born in Iowa. He is living with his parents, 2 brothers, a sister and 2 lodgers, in Washington street, Waterloo, Black Hawk, Iowa, USA. (Supervisors District 6, Enumeration District 7-19, Sheet 22A).

In the 1940 US Census, he is listed as Carl Grahm (sic), a US Army soldier, aged 21 and born in Iowa. He is living with many other soldiers, in Fort Des Moines, Polk, Iowa. In 1935 he was living in Waterloo, Iowa. (Supervisors District 6, Enumeration District 77-8, Sheet 1B).

In the 1950 US Census, he is listed as Carl B. Graham, a Tractor Factory Machine Repairer aged 32 and born in Iowa. He is living with his wife and 5 sons in 714 Hartman, Waterloo, Black Hawk, Iowa. (1950: Waterloo, Black Hawk, Iowa; Roll: 714; Sheet Number: 4; Enumeration District: 104-51).

GENERAL NOTES: Son of Benjamin Wilson and Alice Maud (Gore) Graham.

OBITUARY: The Courier (Waterloo, Iowa) - 20 Mar 1994, Sun - Page 23:

Carl B Graham, 76, of 800 Hickory Ave. died at home Thursday, March 17 of natural causes.

He was born March 17, 1918, in Waterloo, son of Ben and Alice Gore Graham. He married Nellie Argall on March 1, 1941, in Cedar Falls, and she preceeded him in death. He then married Shirley Heidemann on Nov. 24, 1972, in Independence, and she preceeded him in death.

Mr. Graham was employed with Deere and Co. for 33 years, retiring in 1974. He served in the Horse Cavarly in the US Army from 1937 to 1940 and reinlisted in the Army Airborne from 1944 to 1945.

Survived by: four sons, Tom, Joe, Mike and Mark, all of Watereloo; two stepdaughters, Linda McClain of Washburn and Leslie Heidemann of Arizona; a stepson, Jeff Heidemann of Waterloo; 12 grandchildren; four stepgrandchildren; nine greatgrandchildren; a special friend, Dorothy Lofstuen of Cedar Falls.

Preceeded in death by: a son, Pat; two brothers, Floyd and Ransom, and a sister, Nadine Hole.

Services: 10.30 a.m. Monday at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church, with burial in Calvary Cemetery. Full military rites will be conducted by Cedar Falls AMVETS Post 49. Friends may call from 3 to 9 p.m. todayat O'Keefe & Towne - Grarup & Waychoff Funeral Home, where there will by a 7 p.m. Masonic Service by Martin Lodge No. 624 AF&AM. Visitationalso an hour before services Mondat at the church.

Memorial fund: has been established.

In the 1910 US Census, she is listed as Nina A Gratz, a Teacher aged 22 and born in Canada. She is living as a Lodger in Ward 8 of Denver City with her mother, stepfather and another person. She immigrated in 1896. (Supervisors District 1, Enumeration District 96, Sheet 16A).

In the 1920 US Census, she is listed as Nina Gratz, a Teacher aged 30 and born in Canada. She is living in Denver, Colorado, with her mother, stepfather, and a boarder. (Supervisors District 1, Enumeration District 202, Sheet 4B).

In the 1930 US Census, she is listed as Nina Argall aged 46, and born in Canada. She is living at 704 East Avenue, Rifle Town, Garfield County, Colorado with her husband, and two daughters. (Enumeration District 23-22, Supervisors District 5, Sheet 4A).

In the 1940 US Census, she is listed as Nina Argall, a teacher in citizenship and English, aged 56 and born in Canada. She is living with her husband and 2 daughters in South Adams, Denver, Colorado. (Supervisors District 1, Enumeration District 16-108, Sheet 7B).

In the 1950 US Census, she is listed as Nina A. Argall, a City School Supply Teacher aged 66 and born in Canada. OBITUARY: The Anaconda Standard (Anaconda, Montana), August 8th, 1910:

James Gray, one of the best old-time mining men of Butte, who came here over 30 years ago, died Saturday night at his home near Elkhorn, Mont. after a short illness. His body was brought to Butte last night and is at Richards Undertaking Rooms.

Mr Gray was 61 years of age, and came to Butte in 1878. He was a widower and leaves three sons. He was a brother of the late John Gray, who was at one time chief of police of Butte, and who died a year ago at Phoenix, Ariz.

The plans for Mr Gray's funeral have not yet been made, but will be announced later. He was a member of the Knights of Pythlas Lodge at Marysville, Mont.
